video.title: The Rogue Prince of Persia | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: &quot;Eugh, Yahtzee,

I&#39;m a huge, whining bellend, and I want to know 
where the Borderlands 4 review is so I can know

how effectively picking up lots of color-coded 
guns can silence the tacit disapproval of a

society in which I am mentally ill-equipped to 
participate.&quot; Shut up, huge, whining bellends;

I&#39;m working on it. In the meantime, how about we 
talk about some double-A games or perhaps even

single-A games—if you can deign to slum it that 
low—that are actually really good and aspire to

do more than numb the voices. &quot;I dunno, Yahtz. I 
am literally unable to engage with anything that

isn&#39;t a pre-existing IP because corporate media 
has turned me into a hybrid of ATM machine and

sex trafficking victim that runs on sugar and 
makes hooting noises whenever it sees a slow

fade-in on a logo it recognizes.&quot; Well then, allow 
me to operate within those parameters. Shinobi:

Art of Vengeance is a pretty good 2D game 
based on a classic retro IP, full of fancy,

arcadey combat to remind you of how great 2D games 
could be back in the day and a couple of side-on

autoscroll flying levels so you also don&#39;t forget 
how fucking godawful a lot of them were as well.

And then there&#39;s today&#39;s subject, The Rogue Prince 
of Persia. Which is exactly what it sounds like:

a 2D Prince of Persia game but roguelike. It&#39;s 
been out a while, but only now have I found even

the slightest potential gap in the schedule I 
can crowbar in a video about it. Yeah, I know

it&#39;s Ubisoft continuing to yank on the brittle, 
black teats of an already tortured IP, but I guess

the cow was having one of its better days on this 
occasion. Like, the sun was out, and the milking

machine got a new coat of Vaseline. Besides, I&#39;ve 
sort of come to terms with IP milking. If a giant,

cosmic butthole like Ubisoft is pooing out 
some of its foul-smelling money into small,

talented developers making interesting new games 
and all we have to do in return is put up with

them slapping on a recognizable name, then fuck 
it, if that&#39;s what it takes. Make a new tasty and

nutritious breakfast cereal and market it as 
Andrew Lloyd Webber-Os and I&#39;ll still eat it,

although I might have to turn the box to face 
the wall. In the Rogue Prince of Persia, we are

a Prince of Persia, which automatically puts it 
above The Lost Crown in the authenticity stakes.

As tends to be case with Princes of Persia, 
we are a swaggering, overconfident prick

who makes an appointment with Dr. Army of 
dark magic-wielding Huns and ends up being

prescribed a dose of boots to be administered 
as a suppository. Fortunately, he has a magic

necklace that brings him back to life at the 
last place he slept and so must now repeat the

same day over and over again to rescue his family 
members from the conquered city, rewrite events,

and defeat those pesky Huns once and for all. 
And thus begins an action platform roguelike best

approximated to a side-on Hades-like with more of 
a traversal focus. But it&#39;s a pretty sharp focus,

like some fucking XLR shit, &#39;cause the traversal 
works very well. The traditional Prince of Persia

wall run can now be pointed in a direction 
as long as there&#39;s still some wall to run on,

and there&#39;s a combo system that ups your speed if 
you hop rhythmically across poles and shit without

stopping, which has that lovely, cathartic effect 
one attains from seeing a shitting dog getting

a really neat spiral going. Also, the traversal 
movements transition in and out of combat about

as smoothly and efficiently as this review 
just did. I mean, probably even better than

the Sands of Time trilogy, actually, and like a 
Rastafarian minister, that&#39;s pretty high praise.

You can stab a dude, vault over him, kick him 
towards a spike pit, and be on your merry way.

And then make your merry way back again because he 
wasn&#39;t close enough to the spike pit and you need

to kick him again, but never mind. So, the primary 
gameplay loop is about as solid as they get,

and in a roguelike setup (that is to say, &quot;do 
the primary gameplay loop over and over again

forever&quot;), that&#39;s, like, 90% of the job, but I&#39;m 
fond of what Rogue Pee Oh Pee does with the story

side of things too. See, a lot of roguelikes will 
just go, &quot;Get through all the levels and fight the

boss and keep trying until you do it properly, 
fuckface,&quot; in RoguePop, you&#39;re also conducting

an investigation to save your family; you pick 
up leads and information on new areas you won&#39;t

be able to visit until the next run. Like, you 
notice everyone avoiding a specific public toilet

in area 5 and go, &quot;Wait a second, that smells like 
mum&#39;s beer farts,&quot; so you know in the next run to

check the beer garden in area 2, and that&#39;s how 
you track her down. The game also does a number

of fun things with the temporal continuity of a 
run. That number being one. It does one thing.

If you beat a certain boss early on, they don&#39;t 
show up to lightly harass you in one subsequent

area. Fuckin&#39; wow, choices matter. I wish the game 
had leaned more into this kind of thing. In fact,

all told, the game&#39;s strong core goes a bit limp 
and floppy towards the end. I beat the final boss

and thought, &quot;Well, that was weirdly easy&quot; and 
of course, the game went, &quot;Ah ah ah! You haven&#39;t

beaten the proper final boss yet &#39;cause you need 
to finish all the side investigation stuff!&quot; So

then, I do that and save all my family members, 
and they all come together for the big finish,

and so I beat the final boss again and said, 
&quot;Wait, that was still weirdly easy. The Act 2

boss was harder than that, and he telegraphed shit 
like fucking Napoleonic France. I thought you said

there was gonna be a proper final boss.&quot; &quot;I lied! 
PBBBBT.&quot; So frankly, while I was having a lot of

fun playing RogoPoPo at the time, I came away from 
it feeling disappointed. There wasn&#39;t enough meat

on the bone. Maybe grinding away at that one 
gank squad in Silksong for two whole afternoons

caused me to inadvertently ascend to elite-level 
gamer status &#39;cause RoPo was just over too quick.

Surely it&#39;s reasonable to expect some staying 
power from a roguelike, a species of game

motivated to keep you banging your head against 
a series of progressively higher brick walls. So,

to go into the summary, the phrase that leaps 
to mind here is &quot;nice while it lasts.&quot; &quot;Oh,

well, you could always complete all the optional 
monster-hunting challenges,&quot; suggests the game.

&quot;Just kill every enemy 50 times and then again 
in a special way and you will unlock a little

bit of text explaining how best to defeat 
that monster you have already defeated 50

times. Maybe you&#39;ll unlock a new costume to 
further appreciate the game&#39;s actually rather

flat and insipid art style now we&#39;ve spent a lot 
of time looking at it.&quot; Yeah, I suspect I&#39;m done,

game. Not that I dislike the writing. I like the 
little touch where the prince&#39;s family members

are actually a little bit pissed off to know 
that the prince has had Groundhog Day powers

all along. &quot;What? We spent valuable resources 
to rescue a functionally immortal dude? I mean,

that we could forgive, but Bill Murray 
used his infinite free time to learn

how to sculpt ice and play piano, and 
you&#39;ve just been hanging out in your room,

weakly jerking off.&quot; &quot;That&#39;s hardly fair. 
I&#39;m actually very good at jerking off now.&quot;
